ground_truth: As Purvis struggles against the angry civilian, Winstead advances. Dillinger sees him just feet away gripping a pistol. Slack-jawed, Purvis relaxes his aim as Winstead lines up a shot. The bullet pierces the back of Dillinger's skull and exits through his cheek, spewing blood and tissue. Two crimson stains bloom on his shirt front, as Hurt fires twice from behind. Dillinger falls face down, eyes staring off, as blood streams from his ruptured cheek. Purvis stares, then ventures forward. As Dillinger lies dying, his lips move. Winstead removes his hat, crouches and leans his ear close to Dillinger. The agent narrows his eyes, glances at the fallen man, and withdraws, revealing Dillinger's lifeless stare. Winstead gets to his feet, his sober gaze locked on the dead man. He holsters his gun and Purvis joins his side. As the younger G-man eyes the body, Winstead dons his hat, his air stoic and grim. The older man faces him. Purvis eyes him long and steady. Winstead glances away, then looks Purvis in the eye. Marty leans in for a good look at Dillinger's body, then heads off. Polly averts her gaze. Purvis takes another look at the body. A dozen civilians from the movie house rubber-neck as they move closer to the scene. A few yards off, Anna glances over her shoulder and slips away. Before the growing crowd, a man lights a flare and holds it aloft. A few men swap grins and chat. The scene draws more Chicagoans from across the street, and more flares illuminate the area with searing light. The armed federal agents struggle to maintain order. Someone's hand blocks our view. A camera flashes over Dillinger's body. Winstead lights a cigarette and pensively looks away. More onlookers converge on the scene. Policemen help the agents manage pushy photographers. Purvis leaves the scene, silhouetted against the flares' sallow light. Behind him, the glow and the smoke fill the air, blotting the crowd from view. More civilians rush in. From overhead, we gaze down at the chaos, as we withdraw. Winstead sits at a table in a small room with white brick walls. In a cellblock, a matron escorts Billie. Clad in a simple gray dress, she wears a dull expression. As the matron ushers her to another, the prisoner maintains her dispassionate gaze. In the visiting room, the door opens. Winstead stands as Billie enters. She stares guardedly at him, then takes the seat facing his. Winstead sits. Leaning forward, he faces her with a knitted brow. Billie swallows, blinks her glistening eyes, then gives a stony nod. Billie glares coldly. Winstead opens a gold cigarette case and briefly thumbs the contents. He turns the case, offering the grieving woman a cigarette.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: As Purvis wrestles in a tense and challenging struggle with the furious civilian, Winstead makes his way forward with determination. In the midst of this intense scene, Dillinger catches sight of Winstead, standing just a few feet away from him and holding a firmly gripped pistol. In a moment of disbelief, Purvis slackens his aim, allowing Winstead to carefully align his shot. The bullet makes its deadly path, piercing through the back of Dillinger's skull and exiting with force through his cheek, expelling a violent burst of blood and tissue. Two vivid crimson stains rapidly spread on the front of his shirt, creating a grim pattern, as Hurt fires two additional shots from behind, adding to the chaos. Dillinger collapses to the ground, his body falling face down, as his eyes stare blankly, while blood continues to stream from his ruptured cheek wound. Purvis is left staring, frozen momentarily before he bravely ventures forward. As Dillinger lies on the brink of death, his lips begin to move faintly. Winstead, showing a moment of respect, removes his hat, crouches down, and leans his ear intimately close to Dillinger's mouth. Narrowing his eyes to focus, the agent takes a closer look at the fallen man before pulling away, revealing Dillinger's lifeless stare. Winstead rises slowly to his feet, his sober gaze remaining fixed on the now-dead man. With a heavy heart, he holsters his gun, and Purvis comes to join him at his side. As the younger G-man casts his eyes upon the body, Winstead calmly places his hat back on, exuding a stoic and grim demeanor. The older man turns to face him directly. Purvis holds his gaze, long and steady, before Winstead briefly averts his eyes, only to look Purvis directly in the eye once more. Marty leans in closer for a thorough look at Dillinger's lifeless body, then departs from the scene. Polly, unable to bear the sight, turns her gaze away. Purvis takes one more contemplative look at the body. A group of a dozen intrigued civilians, emerging from the movie house, crane their necks as they edge closer to the unfolding scene. A short distance away, Anna glances back over her shoulder before quietly slipping away from the growing commotion. Amidst the increasing crowd, a man strikes a flare and holds it high, its light flickering bravely. A few men exchange knowing grins and engage in hushed chatter. The scene attracts even more Chicagoans from across the busy street, and additional flares illuminate the area with a brilliant, searing light. The armed federal agents strive to maintain control and order. Suddenly, a hand obstructs our view. A camera's flash briefly illuminates Dillinger's prone body. Winstead, with a contemplative air, lights a cigarette and casts his gaze away from the scene. As more and more onlookers converge, policemen step in to aid the agents in managing assertive and eager photographers. Purvis leaves the intense scene, his silhouette distinct against the soft, sallow light of the flares. Behind him, the glow and smoke fill the surrounding air, obscuring the crowd from view. More civilians rush to the scene with urgency. From an overhead vantage point, we look down upon the chaos below, gradually withdrawing from the scene. Winstead finds himself seated at a table in a small room with stark white brick walls. In a nearby cellblock, a matron escorts Billie. Dressed in a simple gray dress, she carries a dull expression on her face. As the matron ushers her toward another room, the prisoner maintains her dispassionate and unwavering gaze. Within the visiting room, the door swings open. Winstead rises from his seat as Billie enters the room. She regards him cautiously, her gaze guarded, before she takes the seat that faces his. Winstead resumes his seat. Leaning forward intently, he faces her, his brow knitted with concern. Billie swallows, blinks her glistening eyes, and offers a stony nod. Her glare remains cold and unwavering. Winstead opens a gold cigarette case, briefly thumbing through the contents before turning the case toward her, offering the grieving woman a cigarette.

test_cases.description: As Purvis grapples with the angry civilian, trying to maintain his balance and grip, Winstead steps forward with deliberate intent. Dillinger, standing just a few feet away, catches sight of Winstead advancing with a pistol firmly gripped in his hand. His mouth falls open in shock, and Purvis, momentarily overwhelmed, eases his aim, allowing Winstead to carefully align his shot. The bullet is released with precision, tearing through the back of Dillinger's skull and making its violent exit through his cheek, sending blood and fragments of tissue spurting outward. Two dark red stains rapidly spread across the front of his shirt as Hurt, positioned behind, fires his gun twice, adding to the chaos. Dillinger collapses forward, his body hitting the ground with a dull thud, his unseeing eyes fixed in a vacant stare as blood flows steadily from his wounded cheek. Purvis, initially frozen, finally moves forward with cautious steps. As Dillinger lies on the ground, clinging to life, his lips move faintly as if trying to form words. Winstead, witnessing this, respectfully removes his hat, crouches down, and leans in closely to catch any last whispered words from the dying man. His eyes narrow as he listens intently, then pulls back to reveal Dillinger's lifeless eyes staring blankly into nothing. Rising to his feet, Winstead stares solemnly at the now-deceased Dillinger, his expression grave as he carefully holsters his gun. Purvis steps up beside him, and as Winstead places his hat back on his head, the air between them turns somber and heavy. The older man, Winstead, turns to face Purvis, who returns the gaze with a long, steady look, a silent exchange passing between them. Winstead briefly glances away before meeting Purvis's eyes once more. Marty leans in closer to scrutinize Dillinger’s lifeless form, then steps away from the scene. Polly, unable to bear the sight, turns her head. Purvis, still processing the event, takes another moment to look down at Dillinger's body. Nearby, a dozen civilians who had emerged from the movie theater edge closer, craning their necks for a better view. A few yards away, Anna, sensing the swelling crowd, glances back one last time before quietly retreating. Amidst the growing throng, a man ignites a flare, holding it high to cast an eerie glow over the scene. Some men within the crowd exchange knowing smiles and engage in hushed conversations. The spectacle pulls more Chicagoans from across the street, drawn by the commotion, as additional flares light up the surroundings with their fierce brightness. Federal agents, armed and tense, struggle to maintain a semblance of order among the increasingly unruly crowd. Suddenly, someone's hand obstructs the view momentarily, and a camera's flash illuminates Dillinger's body in stark relief. Winstead, seemingly unfazed, lights a cigarette, his gaze momentarily drifting as he smokes. The scene continues to attract more onlookers, their numbers swelling by the minute. Policemen step in, offering assistance to the agents in controlling the aggressive photographers. In the midst of the chaos, Purvis makes his exit, his silhouette starkly outlined against the yellowish glow of the flares. As he walks away, the thick haze of smoke and light envelops the area, shrouding the lingering crowd from sight. More civilians continue to surge forward, drawn by the spectacle. As if viewing from above, the chaos below is laid bare, yet steadily fades from view as we retreat from the scene. In another part of the building, Winstead finds himself seated at a table within a small room characterized by stark white brick walls. Meanwhile, in a different section, a matron guides Billie through a cellblock. Dressed in an unadorned gray dress, her face is set in a bland expression devoid of emotion. As the matron leads her towards another destination, Billie maintains her unyielding gaze, her demeanor unchanged. In the visiting room, the door swings open, revealing Winstead standing as Billie steps inside. Her eyes, wary and guarded, fix on him before she takes her place on the chair opposite. Winstead follows suit, sitting down to face her, his brow furrowed in thought. Billie takes a moment, swallowing hard, her eyes shimmering with unshed tears, then manages to acknowledge him with a curt nod, masking her grief with a hard stare. In response, Winstead retrieves a gold cigarette case from his pocket, his fingers brushing lightly over the neatly arranged cigarettes inside before he turns it toward Billie, silently offering her a cigarette in a gesture of shared solace amidst the somber exchange.

test_cases.description: As Purvis struggles against the angry civilian in the bustling streets of Chicago during the intense summer of 1934, Winstead advances with determination. Dillinger, a notorious bank robber who has just left the Biograph Theater, sees him just feet away gripping a pistol. Slack-jawed, Purvis relaxes his aim as Winstead, an experienced agent known for his sharpshooting skills, lines up a shot. The bullet pierces the back of Dillinger's skull and exits through his cheek, spewing blood and tissue. Two crimson stains bloom on his shirt front, as Hurt, another agent loyal to Purvis's leadership, fires twice from behind. Dillinger falls face down, eyes staring off, as blood streams from his ruptured cheek. Purvis, who led this high-profile manhunt, stares, then ventures forward. As Dillinger lies dying, his lips move in what some believe to be his final words. Winstead removes his hat, a sign of respect, crouches and leans his ear close to Dillinger. The agent narrows his eyes, glancing at the fallen man whose criminal exploits had captured national attention, and withdraws, revealing Dillinger's lifeless stare. Winstead gets to his feet, his sober gaze locked on the dead man who had once been labeled Public Enemy No. 1. He holsters his gun and Purvis joins his side. As the younger G-man eyes the body, Winstead dons his hat, his air stoic and grim. The older man faces him, sharing a moment of unspoken understanding. Purvis eyes him long and steady, reflecting on the gravity of their mission's culmination. Winstead glances away, then looks Purvis in the eye. Marty, a local reporter eager to catch the scoop, leans in for a good look at Dillinger's body, then heads off to file his story. Polly, a bystander caught in the scene's chaos, averts her gaze. Purvis takes another look at the body, contemplating the end of an era of crime. A dozen civilians from the movie house, drawn by curiosity and the allure of infamy, rubber-neck as they move closer to the scene. A few yards off, Anna, a local resident who had tipped off the authorities, glances over her shoulder and slips away, wishing to avoid the spotlight. Before the growing crowd, a man lights a flare, used to signal authorities and illuminate the area, and holds it aloft. A few men swap grins and chat, caught up in the spectacle of the moment. The scene draws more Chicagoans from across the street, and more flares illuminate the area with searing light. The armed federal agents struggle to maintain order amidst the excitement. Someone's hand blocks our view, a reminder of the press's relentless coverage. A camera flashes over Dillinger's body, capturing the end of a legend. Winstead lights a cigarette with a contemplative air, a common habit among agents to ease tension, and pensively looks away. More onlookers converge on the scene. Policemen help the agents manage pushy photographers eager to capture history. Purvis leaves the scene, silhouetted against the flares' sallow light that casts an eerie glow over everything. Behind him, the glow and the smoke fill the air, blotting the crowd from view. More civilians rush in, eager to witness the aftermath of a national story. From overhead, we gaze down at the chaos, as we withdraw from the frenzy. Winstead sits at a table in a small room with white brick walls, a typical setting for debriefing sessions. In a cellblock, a matron escorts Billie, Dillinger's loyal girlfriend, who had been detained for questioning. Clad in a simple gray dress, she wears a dull expression, a reflection of her grief and the loss of her notorious partner. As the matron ushers her to another room, the prisoner maintains her dispassionate gaze, hiding her emotions. In the visiting room, the door opens. Winstead stands as Billie enters, showing the courtesy of a federal agent despite the circumstances. She stares guardedly at him, then takes the seat facing his. Winstead sits, leaning forward, he faces her with a knitted brow, signaling the seriousness of the conversation to come. Billie swallows, blinks her glistening eyes, then gives a stony nod, acknowledging the situation's gravity. Billie glares coldly, a reflection of her inner turmoil. Winstead opens a gold cigarette case, an item often carried by men of status, and briefly thumbs the contents. He turns the case, offering the grieving woman a cigarette, a gesture of unexpected kindness amidst the somber meeting.

Behind him, the heat and the ash permeate the atmosphere, erasing the assembly from sight. More bakers rush in. From above, we peer down at the mayhem, as we withdraw. Winstead reclines at a bench in a cozy nook with yellow stone walls. In a playroom, a nanny accompanies Billie. Clad in a vivid red jumpsuit, she wears a vacant demeanor. As the nanny guides her to another, the visitor retains her indifferent stare. In the reception chamber, the portal swings open. Winstead rises as Billie enters. She gazes cautiously at him, then occupies the cushion opposite his. Winstead settles. Leaning in, he faces her with a furrowed brow. Billie gulps, closes her sparkling eyes, then gives a stoic bow. Billie frowns harshly. Winstead opens a silver compass and gently fingers the needle. He spins the compass, presenting the amused woman with a candy.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: As Raul battles against the startled musician, Carter retreats. Greenaway notices him just inches away clutching a violin. Wide-eyed, Raul eases his posture as Carter aligns a laugh. The whisper grazes the edge of Greenaway's hat and escapes through his scarf, scattering feathers and dust. Two bright marks appear on his coat sleeve, as Clark dances twice from the side. Greenaway spins sideways, eyes drifting up, as light drips from his torn scarf. Raul watches, then skips forward. As Greenaway lies resting, his fingers twitch. Carter raises his umbrella, crouches and dips his nose close to Greenaway. The clown squints, peeks at the resting figure, and departs, revealing Greenaway's serene smile. Carter stands up, his jovial expression fixed on the quiet figure. He pockets his wand and Raul joins his stance. As the younger performer observes the scene, Carter adjusts his umbrella, his demeanor jolly and upbeat. The shorter figure turns to face him. Raul nods at him short and quick. Carter glances aside, then meets Raul's gaze. Danny kneels in for a close view of Greenaway's position, then wanders off. Lila turns her attention elsewhere. Raul takes another glance at the scene. A dozen singers from the opera house peer around as they wander nearer to the gathering. A few steps away, Beth peeks over her shoulder and drifts away. Among the forming group, a child strikes a drum and waves it around. A few children exchange giggles and play. The gathering attracts more shoppers from the corner shop, and more drums brighten the scene with flashing color. The unarmed circus performers struggle to entertain the audience. Someone's umbrella obscures our perspective. A lens captures light over Greenaway's position. Carter strikes a match and thoughtfully looks off. More children swarm around the spectacle. Vendors assist the performers in handling cheerful dancers. Raul departs the gathering, silhouetted against the drums' glowing color. Behind him, the shimmer and the scent fill the atmosphere, obscuring the place from sight. More onlookers hurry in. From a distance, we observe the harmony, as we float. Carter reclines at a desk in a spacious room with blue painted walls. In a courtyard, a musician leads Rosa. Clothed in a fancy red gown, she wears a joyful expression. As the musician guides her to another, the dancer maintains her lively smile. In the dining room, the window opens. Carter rises as Rosa appears. She gazes curiously at him, then takes the chair opposite his. Carter settles. Leaning back, he regards her with a raised eyebrow. Rosa inhales, blinks her sparkling eyes, then gives a slight bow. Rosa smiles warmly. Carter opens a silver harmonica case and softly taps the contents. He turns the case, offering the cheerful dancer a harmonica.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: As Purvis grapples with a civilian, Winstead steadies his aim. Dillinger, shocked, is shot by Winstead, and another bullet from Hurt hits him. Dillinger falls, dying, as Winstead listens to his final words. Winstead holsters his gun, and Purvis joins him, exchanging a solemn glance. Onlookers from the cinema approach, and Anna slips away. A man ignites a flare, drawing more Chicagoans. The agents manage the crowd as photographers gather, creating chaos. Purvis leaves the scene against the flare-lit backdrop. In a small room, Winstead meets Billie, who is escorted in with a neutral expression. Winstead offers her a cigarette from a gold case, as she reacts coldly.
